{{Infobox military person |honorific_prefix = |name =Sir Douglas Baird |honorific_suffix = |native_name = |native_name_lang = |image = |image_size = |alt = |caption =Sir Douglas Baird |birth_date =1877 |death_date =1963 |birth_place = |death_place = |placeofburial = |placeofburial_label = |placeofburial_coordinates = |nickname = |birth_name = |allegiance ={{flag|United Kingdom}} |branch ={{army|British Raj}} |serviceyears =1897â€“1940 |rank =[[General]] |servicenumber = |unit = |commands =1st/8th Battalion the [[Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders]]
75th Infantry Brigade
[[28th Punjabis|28th Punjab Regiment]]
[[Zhob Brigade]]
[[Belgaum Military School|Senior Officer's School]]
[[Kohat District]]
[[Pune district|Deccan District]]
[[Eastern Command (India)|Eastern Command, India]] |battles =[[World War I]] |battles_label = |awards =*[[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]] *[[Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George]] *[[Companion of the Order of the Star of India]] *[[Distinguished Service Order]] |spouse = |relations = |laterwork = |signature = |website = }} [[General]] '''Sir (Harry Beauchamp) Douglas Baird''' [[Order of the Bath|KCB]], [[Order of St Michael and St George|CMG]], [[Companion of the Order of the Star of India|CIE]], [[Distinguished Service Order|DSO]] (1877-1963) was a [[United Kingdom|British]] officer in the [[Indian Army]]. ==Military career== Baird was commissioned on the unattached list of the [[Indian Army]] on 20 January 1897.{{LondonGazette|issue=26815|supp=|startpage=342|date=19 January 1897|accessdate=8 June 2013}} He served on the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] in [[World War I]] becoming commanding officer of the 1st/8th Battalion the [[Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders]] in 1916 and then as a General Staff Officer first with [[51st (Highland) Division]] and then with the [[Cavalry Corps (United Kingdom)|Cavalry Corps]] before becoming commander of 75th Infantry Brigade in 1918.[http://www.generals.dk/general/Baird/Sir_Harry_Beauchamp_Douglas/Great_Britain.html Generals.dk] After the War Baird became a General Staff Officer at [[4th Infantry Division (India)|4th Indian Infantry Division]] in India, Brigadier-General on the General Staff with the Baluchistan Force and then commanding officer of the [[28th Punjabis]]. He then became Commander of the [[Zhob Brigade]] in November 1920, Colonel on the Staff at [[India Command|Army Headquarters, India]] in 1923 and Commandant of the [[Senior Officers' School, Belgaum]] in 1924. Baird went on to be Deputy Adjutant and Quartermaster-General in India in July 1929 and General Officer Commanding the [[Kohat District]] in December 1930.[http://www.gulabin.com/armynavy/pdf/Army%20Commands%201900-2011.pdf Army Commands] Then he became General Officer Commanding the [[Pune district|Deccan District]] in 1932 and General Officer Commanding-in-Chief [[Eastern Command (India)|Eastern Command]] in April 1936 before retiring in April 1940. ==References== {{Research help|Mil}} {{reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{s-bef|before=[[Norman MacMullen|Sir Norman MacMullen]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Eastern Command (India)|GOC-in-C, Eastern Command, India]]|years=1936–1940}} {{s-aft|after=[[Charles Broad (British Army officer)|Sir Charles Broad]]}} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baird, Douglas}} [[Category:1877 births]] [[Category:1963 deaths]] [[Category:British Indian Army generals]] [[Category:Knights Commander of the Order of the Bath]] [[Category:Companions of the Order of St Michael and St George]] [[Category:Companions of the Order of the Star of India]] [[Category:Companions of the Distinguished Service Order]]
